node.text:
Artadi owner/winemaker Carlos Lopez de Lacalle says the 2018 vintage came from a warm summer with a slightly cold September. "From that we got all this fresh, elegant, ripe fruit aromas with great balance and a lot of tension." James says the Artadi 2018 wines are good now, but asks Carlos how he thinks they will age. "For us, a wine that ages needs to be drinkable when it's young," Carlos says, adding that he's certain the 2018s will age, given their ripe tannins and higher acidity. "Now if you taste your wines, if you want to make comparisons it's like Burgundy now," James said of the 2018s compared with 10 years ago. "It's really just fresh, and really fine tannins ... and you can see the differences in all the different crus, and I think that's really exciting."

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com has always promoted village and sub-appellations for Chianti Classicos, and we are happy the rule changes pertaining to the sub-appellations are taking effect. 

Our video series on Chianti Classicos covers each comune, and includes interviews with owners, enologists and members of the Chianti Classico Consortium. It looks at their wines, their comunes, the history and the future of Chianti Classico. 

Of all the comunes of Chianti Classico, the two we'll meet in episode eight are without a doubt the least known of all: Tavarnelle Val di Pesa and Poggibonsi. Given their relative obscurity, we thought it a good idea to group them together. Most of the land in these two comunes isn't actually Chianti Classico at all, extending instead into the realms of just Chianti. Both also give home to the largest and most urbanized towns of the region. 

Nevertheless, there are one or two excellent producers who fight against the odds. One is Johannes Davaz, a Swiss whose relatives still make pinot near Lichtenstein. Today he owns his own small but first-class property in Tavarnelle Val di Chianti Classico called "Poggio Al Sole." He explains how it can be difficult making wine in an unknown area, especially since he feels his wines belong more to the much better-known comune of Greve. 

In the comune of Poggibonsi, there are only two serious wine producers. Cinciano is one of them, but as commercial director Angelo Dalbello explains, the comune has always been important for other reasons – back in medieval times it was an important stop on the ancient Via Francigena, one of the great ways of the ancient world. 

Similarly to Tavarnelle, it's an especially frustrating situation for Cinciano because their winery actually sits on a hill above the large town, where, as Angelo asserts, ventilation, exposure and soils are all top quality. Angelo is looking to promote his brand first and foremost. He makes a good point that when it comes to quality – ultimately it's up to the producer to prove his worth. 

#Italy #ItalianWine #ChiantiClassico #ChiantiClassicoDiaries #wine #winenerd #winestagram #winery #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling

node.title: CHIANTI CLASSICO DIARIES: TAVARNELLE VAL DI PESA POGGIBONSI

node.text:
James recently tasted the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum, which impressed him so much he said to Lucie Pereyre de Nonacourt, who represents the fourth generation at Champagne Laurent-Perrier, and Edouard Cossy, the company's global director: "The aromas were amazing. Honestly, I can't think of a more beautiful Champagne with the aromas... that sort of brioche and tarte au limon." 

Lucie tells the story of how her grandfather founded the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée. When he became director of the house, he realized he had to have a prestige cuvée. He based the creation of his cuvée on a unique blend, which would take the champagne further in terms of quality and thus achieve his goal of recreating the perfect year – "one that nature cannot provide." 

Check out their conversation now to learn more about the Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum and when to expect its release.

node.text:
American Pinot Noir producer Adam Lee wears many hats: he was a co-founder of Siduri Wines (and remains a consultant and winemaker), founded the Clarice Wine Company, and co-founded Beau Marchais Wine with famed vintner Philippe Cambie. 

In this chat with JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt, Adam talks about his approach in making pinot through whole-cluster fermentation and why he varied whole-cluster percentages for the 2017-19 vintages. Claire also asks Adam for his thoughts on the uncertainty of the final product and whether whole-cluster fermentation can affect a wine negatively, to which Adam responds: "Yes, there is a risk you could have unripe stems ... [but] one of the things I have found on stem ripeness is it has to do with the length of hang time and does not correlate with sugar maturity." 

Check out the rest of their conversation for more of Adam's thoughts on pinots and their future on the West Coast.

#California #CalifornianWine #ClariceWineCompany @claricewinecompany #BeauMarchaisWine @beaumarchaiswines #pinotnoir #westcoastwines #wine #winemaker #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
Great Wines of the World Grand Masterclass began today featuring 177 wines from 88 wineries. Wine trade and keen consumers were happy to compare vintages, regions, countries as well as try lots of new releases. 

James gave some advice on tasting strategies for the Masterclass and wines and vintages not to miss.

node.text:
James sits down with Michel Friou and Manuel Louzada, the winemaker and managing director, respectively, at Viña Almaviva in Chile to discuss the 2019 Epu, which James calls a "beautiful second wine." 

"One question is, how did you finally decide to do a second wine and why?" James asks Manuel. "It's a very delicious wine." 

"After 25 years we definitely believed that we already have brand recognition, brand awareness, that Almaviva was already recognized because of the quality of the wine and because of its reputation," Manuel says. "From a business standpoint, the decision was, 'Let's focus on Almaviva ... and then afterward we started again in 2006 [with Epu] ... in basically two markets: Chile and Brazil.'" 

They also talk about the decision to sell Epu through La Place de Bordeaux, where negociants will redistribute it throughout the world. Check out the video now for the full conversation. 

#Chile #ChileanWine #MaipoValley #MaipoValleyWine #Almaviva #AlmavivaWinery #AlmavivaWine @almavivawinery  #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt sits down with Domaine Serene Winemaker Michael Fay to ask about the proportion of pinot noir versus chardonnay grapes used at the winery, as well as its plans for making more chardonnay. 

"We're definitely bullish on chardonnay," Michael says. "We really believe in three things for chardonnay that really make this style of chardonnay that we want. We're really only interested in planting chardonnay in high elevations, on Jory soils ... and using Dijon clones, which are early-ripening clones of chardonnay." 

Watch their video interview for free now at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Florent Genty, commercial director of Chateau Nenin, presents Chateau Nenin Pomerol 2018. This wine will be shown at the Grand Tasting Sessions held at Four Seasons Hotel Hong Kong from Sept. 2-3. 

Chateau Nenin is a large estate by Pomerol standards, with 32 hectares of vineyards in production. The owners of this estate, the Delons who also own the famous second growth of Leoville Las Cases, are starting to use this to their advantage, making rigorous selections at harvest time and favoring low-yielding, older vines. The fine tannins in these silky Right Bank wines make them ethereal — try them for yourself and you’ll soon understand why.

node.text:
James sits down with Napa Valley winemaker Andy Erickson to talk about how the current Napa harvest is going and how it compares with previous years. They also taste the 2018 Favia wines and 2019 Leviathan California. 

James says of the Leviathan, "It's sort of fruit-forward ... but at the same time remains really agile and fresh," and asks Andy the secret behind it. 

"I just wanted a wine that you could go out to a steakhouse and if I saw it on the menu, I would want it," Andy says. "This is the wine I like to drink. It's rich, it's flavorful, it's very fresh, and it's got the structure of a Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon and sort of that character, but it's made from different varieties – it's cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc, merlot, syrah and now even a little petite syrah."

node.text:
In this Tasting Interview, associate editor Claire Nesbitt and winemaker Veronique Boss-Drouhin of Domaine Drouhin consider the 2019 vintage - the terroir, soils and climate in Willamette, but also the 2020 vintage and how smoke taint could be an issue. Followed by this was their discussion on the unique spicy nature and fine-grained tannins of the Oregon pinot, and the potential for chardonnay in the region.

node.text:
Associate Editor Claire Nesbitt speaks with Tom Gerrie, winegrower and second-generation owner of Cristom Vineyards in Willamette Valley, Oregon, on how the state's pinot noirs compare with those from Sonoma County, California. Tom describes Oregon's fruit as "relatively bright. it's relatively high-toned, relatively red-fruited for the most part. I do think we have some differences based on soil... Our [deep] volcanic soils are extremely bright and red-fruited. Very, very high tone and very floral." Check out the video to hear Tom's thoughts on why Oregon chardonnays lag pinot noirs in popularity, and on his hopes for riesling.

node.text:
Reaching #10 on our list of Top 100 Wines of 2020 is the Christmann Riesling Pfalz Idig GG 2019, which scored 99 points. 

“The deepest waters are the most mysterious, because you look ever further down and never know what you’re going to discover another five fathoms deeper. And just so, this beautiful riesling has seductive fruit that drags you into an abyss of beauty and joy,” the JamesSuckling.com Tasting Team said about this wine. “What stunning texture, and what a long, refined finish.” 

To find out more details on our Top 100 Wines of 2020 from Germany, and to see more of our Top 100 lists, please visit JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
One of the top wines from our August monthly tasting report was the Muller-Catoir Riesling Pfalz Burgergarten Im Breumel GG 2020, which continues Muller-Catoir's streak in offering some of the best dry whites in Germany. 

Our tasters found “ripe white-peach, tangerine and passion-fruit aromas” and “delicate floral notes” in this youthful dry riesling, with a focused brightness on the concentrated palate.

You can find out which other wines impressed during our August tastings of 2,300-plus wines at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Day 3 of masterclasses at James Suckling Wine Central hosted by JamesSuckling.com's tasters Claire Nesbitt and Kevin Davy today focused on red wines from Rioja. They discussed the differences between the different styles and maturation of Crianza, Reserva and Gran Reserva wines.
 
Rioja continues to impress as a region of great value and cellar-worthy wines, with a diverse range of styles. Guests compared a selection of wines from the excellent 2010 vintage from three top Bodegas. They enjoyed the balance, harmony and freshness of the wines and were particularly impressed by the complexity of some of the iconic Gran Reservas in this horizontal tasting.

node.text:
Patricia Toth, winemaker at Planeta Wine in Sicily, presents Planeta Carricante Sicilia Eruzione 1614 2018, which was shown at the Autumn Edition Grand Tasting Sessions at the Four Seasons Hotel Hong Kong last week. 

The Planeta family brought Sicily to the forefront of Italian winemaking in the late 1990s by using international grape varietals such as chardonnay and merlot. The first winery was built in 1994, and later in 1997 the Dorilli estate was acquired. Further purchases, including 12 terraces on the northern slopes of Mount Etna in 2008, increased the total vineyard area to 35 hectares. And it’s the indigenous grape types that are shining now. With varieties such as carricante and nero d’avola, Planeta is showcasing a more reserved style, meaning more drinkability and better quality, all produced under the protocol SOStain to increase sustainability.

node.text:
Artadi owner/winemaker Carlos Lopez de Lacalle says the 2018 vintage came from a warm summer with a slightly cold September. "From that we got all this fresh, elegant, ripe fruit aromas with great balance and a lot of tension." James says the Artadi 2018 wines are good now, but asks Carlos how he thinks they will age. "For us, a wine that ages needs to be drinkable when it's young," Carlos says, adding that he's certain the 2018s will age, given their ripe tannins and higher acidity. "Now if you taste your wines, if you want to make comparisons it's like Burgundy now," James said of the 2018s compared with 10 years ago. "It's really just fresh, and really fine tannins ... and you can see the differences in all the different crus, and I think that's really exciting." 

#Spain #SpanishWine #Rioja #ArtadiBodegas #ArtadiWines @artadi_eus #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
Coming in at #6 on our list of Top 100 Wines of France in 2020 was the Château d'Yquem Sauternes 2017. 

Our tasters said this bottle delivers “thrilling purity and intensity,” with the nose offering “aromas of fresh and dried apricot and peach pastry, as well as freshly baked creme brulee, candied and fresh orange and kumquat.” 

The 2017 Yquem is a very powerful wine from a very rich and exceptional vintage, and the acidity has a big hand in balancing the richness. Great quality and one of the best since the legendary 2001. Drink or hold. 

For more details on our Top 100 Wines of France in 2020, and to see more of our Top 100 reports, please click on the link in the bio or visit JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Portugal’s Douro Valley holds a special place in my heart. The only wine book I ever wrote was about the valley and Port. Thanks for a beautiful video @dows_port #repost Repost from @dows_port
•
All looks calm at Quinta do Bomfim. Quiet. Peaceful. Behind the scenes, though, our team are busy ensuring we are prepared for this year’s harvest. 

There’s a growing sense of anticipation. Great expectations for the grapes we will pick, and the wines we will make. 

--

Tudo parece calmo na Quinta do Bomfim. Silêncio, tranquilidade. Paz. Nos bastidores, no entanto, a nossa equipa está ocupada a garantir os preparativos para a vindima deste ano. 

Há uma crescente sensação de antecipação. Grandes expectativas para as uvas que vamos colher e os vinhos que vamos produzir.

#dowsport #portwine #dowsvintageport #vintageport #quintadobomfim

node.text:
THE MONTHLY TASTING REPORT FOR AUGUST IS OUT NOW ON JAMESSUCKLING.COM 

Out of the 2300+ wines that were uncorked and rated by the JamesSuckling.com Tasting Team in August, a Spanish Rioja from Telmo Rodriguez and two German Rieslings all received a full 100 points each. 

James called the Compañia de Vinos Telmo Rodriguez Rioja Las Beatas 2018 a “magical wine that shows mind-blowing pedigree and length.” 

Meanwhile Senior Editor Stuart Pigott’s recent tastings in Germany led him to Weingut Keller’s Riesling Rheinhessen Brunnenhausen ABTS E GG 2020, which confirmed his initial thought that Germany would produce at least a few extraordinary bottles from the 2020 vintage, as well as to the excellent Robert Weil Riesling Rheingau Kiedrich Grafenberg Trockenbeerenauslese 2020, a rare sweet wine. For tasting notes and more on the other wines that were tasted in August, visit the link in bio.

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com has always promoted village and sub-appellations for Chianti Classicos, and we are happy the rule changes pertaining to the sub-appellations are taking effect. 

Our video series on Chianti Classicos covers each comune, and includes interviews with owners, enologists and members of the Chianti Classico Consortium. It looks at their wines, their comunes, the history and the future of Chianti Classico. 

Of all the comunes of Chianti Classico, the two we'll meet in episode eight are without a doubt the least known of all: Tavarnelle Val di Pesa and Poggibonsi. Given their relative obscurity, we thought it a good idea to group them together. Most of the land in these two comunes isn't actually Chianti Classico at all, extending instead into the realms of just Chianti. Both also give home to the largest and most urbanized towns of the region. 

Nevertheless, there are one or two excellent producers who fight against the odds. One is Johannes Davaz, a Swiss whose relatives still make pinot near Lichtenstein. Today he owns his own small but first-class property in Tavarnelle Val di Chianti Classico called "Poggio Al Sole." He explains how it can be difficult making wine in an unknown area, especially since he feels his wines belong more to the much better-known comune of Greve. 

In the comune of Poggibonsi, there are only two serious wine producers. Cinciano is one of them, but as commercial director Angelo Dalbello explains, the comune has always been important for other reasons – back in medieval times it was an important stop on the ancient Via Francigena, one of the great ways of the ancient world. 

Similarly to Tavarnelle, it's an especially frustrating situation for Cinciano because their winery actually sits on a hill above the large town, where, as Angelo asserts, ventilation, exposure and soils are all top quality. Angelo is looking to promote his brand first and foremost. He makes a good point that when it comes to quality – ultimately it's up to the producer to prove his worth. 

#Italy #ItalianWine #ChiantiClassico #ChiantiClassicoDiaries #wine #winenerd #winestagram #winery #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling

node.text:
Andrea Sauska of Sauska Wineries in Hungary presents Sauska Furmint Tokaj Birsalmás 2018, which was shown at the Autumn Edition Grand Tasting Sessions at the Four Seasons Hotel Hong Kong last week. 

Under the philosophy of using only the power of gravity and ambient yeasts to craft their wines, Sauska grows both indigenous and international grape varieties in Tokaj (in northeastern Hungary) and Villany (in the southwest). The acclaimed oenologist and agronomist Stefano Chioccioli — Sauska’s consultant since 2009 — runs the gamut of wines, producing white and red, still and sparkling, dry and sweet. The clean, balanced and expressive wines that are made from the indigenous grapes (furmint and harslevelu) are truly golden, while some of the single-varietal wines made from international varietals — such as pinot noir, merlot and chardonnay — are equally exciting. Give these lovely Hungarian wines a try. We hope you enjoy tasting them as much as we did!
